From the lessons of the scientific course at Al-Rajhi Mosque in Buraidah for the year 1426 AH.
Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
Part One (Purification - Prayer - Funerals)
Delivered by Sheikh: Prof. Dr. Khalid bin Ali Al-Mushayqih

**Introduction**
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and prayers and peace be upon the Master of Messengers. To proceed:
In this course, I decided that we address 'Contemporary Issues concerned with matters of Worship'. There are many contemporary issues related to purification and prayer, as well as what relates to Zakat and Fasting, such as new invalidate of fasting, etc.
We will start, God willing, with contemporary issues of purification, then after that we will move to contemporary issues of prayer, then after that if time permits us, we will address a number of contemporary issues of Zakat such as the ruling on trading with Zakat funds and charities and other things we will mention. We will try, God willing, to be brief because the contemporary issues are many. I have surveyed many of the contemporary issues existing now in purification; there are many issues found in water, in ablution (Wudu), in bathing (Ghusl), and also regarding removing impurities, etc. These issues are needed by people because they encounter them and they touch their worship matters. We will mention a definition for these contemporary issues in general, then after that mention their derivation from the words of previous jurists.
Before I start with the contemporary issues, I will present a definition of 'Nawazil' (contemporary issues) in language and terminology, then after that I will mention a part of the importance of studying contemporary issues and new occurrences in Fiqh, then after that we will start with the contemporary issues of purification. We will try, God willing, to take ten issues every day.

**Definition of Nawazil**
Nawazil: Plural of Nazilah. In language: The descent of a thing and its coming down.
As for terminology: It is the new occurrence that requires a Sharia ruling.

**Ruling on Studying these Contemporary Issues**
It is a communal obligation (Fard Kifayah); if performed by enough people, the sin falls off the rest. Because clarifying knowledge and what people need is a communal obligation; if performed by enough people, the sin falls off the rest.
The evidence that it is an obligation is the saying of Allah Almighty: {And [mention, O Muhammad], when Allah took a covenant from those who were given the Scripture, [saying], "You must make it clear to the people and not conceal it."} (1). So clarifying knowledge and spreading it is obligatory upon scholars and students of knowledge. For a layperson, deriving the ruling for such contemporary issues based on what came in the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger (peace be upon him) and what the scholars (may Allah have mercy on them) mentioned might not be done well. It was made a communal obligation because this action relates to the deed and not the doer. We have previously clarified in the Fiqh Maxims the difference between communal obligation and individual obligation; that if the matter relates to the doer, it is an individual obligation, and if it relates to the deed, it is a communal obligation. This relates to the deed, meaning the acquisition of this deed is required whether from this person or from others.

**Importance of Studying Contemporary Issues**
Studying contemporary issues has importance. Among its importance:
First: Clarifying the perfection of Sharia and that it is valid for every time and place. There is no contemporary issue except that it has a ruling in Sharia; the explanation of that came in the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger (peace be upon him), known and recognized by those firm in knowledge. The evidence for that is: The saying of Allah Almighty: {This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion} (2). And He Almighty said: {And We have sent down to you the Book as clarification for all things and as guidance and mercy and good tidings for the Muslims} (3). And Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) left us while there was no bird flapping its wings in the sky except that he mentioned to us knowledge about it" (4).

Fourth: Earning reward and recompense from Allah Almighty, because the scholar and Mujtahid, if he exerts his effort and view in learning the ruling of this issue and what its ruling is, there is reward and recompense from Allah Almighty in this. In the Hadith, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "If a judge makes a judgment and strives and is correct, he has two rewards. And if he strives and errs, he has one reward." Agreed upon.

Fifth: Performing this obligation, which is a communal obligation, because as we mentioned before, learning these contemporary issues is a communal obligation. So a person undertaking to know them and clarify them to people is performing one of the obligations of Islam.
Sixth: Granting the one undertaking the study of these issues a Fiqh aptitude (Malakah Fiqhiyyah).
This is a part of the importance and benefits of these contemporary issues.

**Contemporary Issues Related to Rulings of Purification**
The contemporary issues in purification, as we mentioned, are very many. Today we will mention what relates to water issues, and also mention a part of what relates to Wudu and Ghusl issues, and we will complete later, God willing.
Among these issues:
**The First Issue: Water Changed by Rust.**
**The Second Issue: Water Changed by Modern Detergents** such as: water changed by soap and other newly introduced detergents.
So we have these two waters:
First Water: Changed by rust. It is that which changed due to passing through water pipes or due to remaining long in some vessels preserving it like tanks and pots, until its color inclined to redness. So what is the ruling of this water changed by rust regarding Wudu? Does it lift major and minor impurity (Hadath) or not? And does it remove filth (Khabath) or not?
Similarly regarding waters changed by modern detergents, like soap and others. If we find water changed by this soap and the like, does it lift impurity (Hadath) and remove filth (Khabath) or not?
To clarify the ruling of these two issues, we say: Water is divided into categories. Then after that we will derive the ruling of these two issues based on these categories mentioned by scholars, may Allah have mercy on them:
*   **First Category: Water remaining in its original creation**, not changed by impurity nor by a pure substance that transfers it from the name of absolute water (Ma' Mutlaq) and dominates its parts, like henna, ink, or dyes. This water is purifying (Tahur) by agreement of scholars; it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath.
    The evidence for that: The saying of Allah Almighty {And We have sent down from the sky pure water} (1).

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
And also the hadith of Abu Huraira - may Allah be pleased with him - regarding sea water, that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Its water is purifying, its dead animals are lawful." This hadith was narrated by Imam Ahmad, Al-Tirmidhi, Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and others, and its chain of narration is authentic.
*   **Second Category: Water changed by impurity**, its taste changed, or its color changed, or its smell changed. We say this is impure (Najis) water by agreement of scholars.
    The evidence for that: The hadith of Abu Sa'id (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Water is purifying, nothing makes it impure" (1). The Prophet's judgment that water is purifying is exited from this purifying nature by consensus of scholars; for scholars agree that if water is changed by impurity—its taste, smell, or color changes—it is impure; it does not lift Hadath nor remove Khabath.
*   **Third Category: Water changed by something that is usually inseparable from water.** Meaning changed by something accompanying water usually. We say this, by agreement of Imams also, does not strip it of its purifying nature; it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath. This is like water changed by staying for a long time; this is usually inseparable from water, so we say it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath. Water changed by trees existing in it or weeds growing in it; this is usually inseparable from water, so we say it does not strip it of its purifying nature; it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath. Water changed by fish existing in it... etc. Water changed by falling leaves. Water changed by what winds throw into it or floods carry to it... etc.

*   **Fourth Category: Water changed by soil (Turab).** This is also by agreement of Imams considered purifying; it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath. Because soil is a substitute for water, and soil is one of the two purifiers and is a purifier like water. That is why Allah Almighty said regarding soil when mentioning Tayammum: {Allah does not intend to make difficulty for you, but He intends to purify you} (1). And in the authentic hadith of Abu Dharr, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Clean earth is the Wudu of a Muslim even if he does not find water for ten years" (2). So if we have water changed by soil—soil was put in it, or for example a person found a pond in the desert and moved his feet in it until it became red—we say this lifts Hadath and removes Khabath. This is by agreement of Imams, and we mentioned the evidence for that. Unless this water becomes mud, meaning it becomes mud that does not flow over the limbs; in this case, they said it does not lift Hadath nor remove Khabath. But if it is changed by this soil [while still water], they said this does not harm, and it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath.
*   **Fifth Category: Water changed by a pure substance.** For example, changed by henna, or some ink was put in it, or some dyes, or some tea... etc. This changed by a pure substance. This water has details, although there is disagreement among scholars, may Allah have mercy on them. What concerns us is the preponderant opinion in this issue. We say: Water changed by a pure substance, if it strips it of the name of absolute water and dominates its parts, then it transfers from being purifying. We do not say it is purifying that lifts Hadath. But regarding removing Khabath, we say this is another thing, because removing Khabath is broader than lifting Hadath as we will explain, God willing.

**First Issue:** Our water changed by rust, which of these categories is it?

We say that water changed by rust belongs to the category of water changed by something inseparable from it. As we said, water changed by a matter inseparable from it usually, accompanying water usually, is purifying by agreement of Imams. Based on this, we say that water changed by rust: changed by pipe rust, tank rust, or pot rust and the like, we say this is purifying water by agreement of Imams; it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath.

**Second Issue: Water changed by soap and the like... etc.**
This, we say, takes the ruling of the Fifth Category. If this soap by which water changed is a small amount such that it does not change the water [significantly]—does not strip it of the name of absolute water and does not dominate its parts—then we say it is also purifying; it lifts Hadath and removes Khabath. But if this changing agent stripped it of the name of absolute water and dominated its parts, we say it does not lift Hadath. As for removing Khabath, it does remove Khabath as we will explain, God willing.
The Hanafis are the broadest of schools in this issue, meaning regarding lifting Hadath and removing Khabath. They view that water changed by some detergents like soap and other powders existing now... etc., even if it dominates its parts and even if it transfers it from the name of absolute water, they say this lifts Hadath and removes Khabath.
Regarding removing Khabath, water changed by rust also removes Khabath by agreement of Imams.

**Issue: Is water a condition for removing Khabath, or do we say Khabath is removed by any remover?**
There are two opinions of scholars, may Allah have mercy on them:
**First Opinion:** Water is a condition for removing Khabath. This is said by most scholars from the Shafi'is, Malikis, and Hanbalis.
Their evidences:
Among them: The hadith of Anas and Abu Huraira in the story of the Bedouin urinating in the mosque: "That the Prophet (peace be upon him) called for a bucket of water and poured it over it" (Agreed upon).
Among them: The hadith of Asma' (may Allah be pleased with her) regarding menstruation blood, containing the Prophet's saying: "...scrape it off, then rub it with water, then rinse it, then pray in it" (Agreed upon).
And other evidences of theirs.

**Second Opinion:** Water is not a condition for removing Khabath (filth). This is the view of the Hanafis and the choice of Sheikh al-Islam (Ibn Taymiyyah), may Allah have mercy on him.
Their evidences:
Among them: All evidences of Istijmar (cleaning with stones), because the one doing Istijmar wipes the impurity by wiping and does not remove it with water; he wipes it with cloth, soil, stones... etc., and does not remove it with water.
Among them: What is confirmed in Sahih Al-Bukhari (1) from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that she said: "One of us would have only one garment in which she menstruated. If some menstrual blood got on it, she would wet it with her saliva like this and scratch it off with her fingernail."
Among them: The hadith of Abu Sa'id regarding the purification of shoes, that if a person wants to enter the mosque and there is harm (filth) on his shoes, he rubs them with soil; "Soil is their purifier" (2).
Among them: The hadith of Umm Salamah—though it has weakness—regarding a woman's hem dragging as she goes to the market. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "What comes after it purifies it" (3).
**Preponderance:** That water is not a condition for removing Khabath, and this opinion is the correct one.

Based on this, we say this water changed by these detergents, soap or otherwise, if it dominated the parts of the water, does not lift Hadath (ritual impurity), but it removes Khabath (physical filth). Also, we say regarding other things that are not water, such as gasoline, gas, etc., that these things do not lift Hadath but they remove Khabath.

**The Third Issue: Dry Cleaning.**
Dry cleaning is the removal of impurity and dirt using a liquid remover other than water, along with the use of water vapor. This dry cleaning is usually and mostly resorted to for clothes that are affected by water, meaning water spoils them. Sheikh al-Islam and others have stated regarding things that if contaminated and using water harms them, that wiping is sufficient for them, such as banknotes, or papers and documents hit by impurity; if you go and wash them with water, they get spoiled. Sheikh al-Islam gave the example of silk garments; if washed, it would lead to their spoilage. He says wiping is sufficient for these. So anything that if contaminated, washing it with water leads to its damage, spoilage, or harm... etc., wiping is sufficient. Now, something other than wiping exists; dry cleaning or steam laundries exist now. According to the previous issue we mentioned, which is that impurity is purified by any purifier, we say this issue applies, and we say the ruling revolves with its cause (Illah) in existence and non-existence. The cause is the harm (filth); if the harm exists, the ruling remains, and if the harm is negated by any remover, the ruling is negated.

**The Fourth Issue: Artificial Dental Fixtures or Dentures.**
Some people have artificial teeth they install, or some teeth they install, and these teeth are removable. Is it obligatory upon him if he wants to perform Wudu or Ghusl to remove these removable teeth or not?
The famous view of the Hanbali school, may Allah have mercy on them, is that rinsing the mouth (Madmadah) and sniffing water into the nose (Istinshaq) are both obligatory and Fard in Wudu and Ghusl. This is one of the unique views of the Hanbali school.
The Hanafis say that Madmadah and Istinshaq are Fard in Ghusl but not in Wudu.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
The Shafi'is and Malikis say: Madmadah and Istinshaq are two Sunnahs in Wudu and Ghusl. So according to the opinion of the Shafi'is and Malikis, it is not obligatory because they fundamentally see that Madmadah and Istinshaq are each Sunnah. But we remain with the Hanbali school; they see that Madmadah and Istinshaq are both obligatory and Fard in Wudu and Ghusl.
The preponderant of these opinions is the Hanbali school, that Madmadah and Istinshaq are both obligatory and Fard in Wudu and Ghusl.
The evidence for that from the Quran: Allah Almighty said: {O you who have believed, when you rise to [perform] prayer, wash your faces} (1). The nose is part of the face; no one says the nose is not part of the face. The mouth is also part of the face, even if it is a cavity, it is under the ruling of the exterior. That is why if a person rinses his mouth, his fasting is not broken. Also, the hadith of Abu Huraira in the two Sahihs that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Then let him put water in his nose then blow it out." This is a command, and the default in command is obligation. And in the hadith of Safwan, though it has weakness: "If you perform Wudu, then rinse your mouth...". Also, those who described the Wudu of the Prophet (peace be upon him), nearly twenty-two companions, did not mention that the Prophet (peace be upon him) omitted Madmadah and Istinshaq.
Based on this, it remains with us that Madmadah and Istinshaq are obligatory. So, is it obligatory on a person to remove these things [dentures] or not?
The Shafi'is stated that if a person's nose is cut off and he then takes a nose made of gold, as the Prophet (peace be upon him) guided Arfajah bin As'ad when his nose was cut off on the Day of Al-Kulab; he took a nose of silver but it rotted on him, so the Prophet (peace be upon him) guided him to take a nose of gold (2).

The Shafi'is stated that if he takes a nose of gold, this nose takes the ruling of the original nose, so he does not have to remove it but washes it with the face. They also stated that if a person's fingertip is cut off and he takes a gold fingertip instead, he does not have to remove it during Ghusl, and this fingertip is like the original; he washes it.
Based on this, we say the correct view in this issue is: Dentures or artificial teeth do not have to be removed by a person if he wants Wudu or Ghusl. The evidence for this is two proofs:
1.  The hadith of Arfajah bin As'ad (may Allah be pleased with him) "that the Prophet (peace be upon him) ordered him to take a nose of gold" (1). This nose would block some of the water contact areas, yet the Prophet (peace be upon him) did not order him to remove this nose during Wudu or Ghusl.
2.  A person is permitted or prescribed to wear a ring, yet it was not reported that he must take off the ring or move it, even though the ring might block some water. The Prophet (peace be upon him) also wore a ring (2), yet it was not reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to move his ring—that was not established—or that he used to take off his ring. Since that was not reported, it indicates that such things are excused. The ring blocks part of the finger, so this is excused. We say such a fixture [denture], even if removable, taking it off might involve some hardship. So we say it is not removed or moved. Just as the ring which is permitted or prescribed for a person to wear does not have to be removed, so too dentures do not have to be removed.

**The Fifth Issue: Painting Nails with Chemical Substances (Nail Polish).**
This issue, although clear, I mentioned because some Muftis stated that it takes the ruling of Khuff (leather socks) and that it is okay for a woman to wipe over it for a day and a night.

This polish, although it has some harm, if a woman puts on such things at the time of Wudu or Ghusl, this is forbidden and impermissible because encompassing the limb with washing is obligatory. The Imams (Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, and Hanbali) all agree that one of the conditions for the validity of Wudu is removing what prevents water from reaching the skin.
The evidence for that: The saying of Allah Almighty: {O you who have believed, when you rise to [perform] prayer, wash your faces and your hands to the elbows and wipe over your heads and wash your feet to the ankles} (1). Allah Almighty commanded washing the hand, which includes the entire hand, and commanded washing the two feet, which includes the entire feet, even the nails. Whoever adopts this barrier (nail polish) which prevents water from reaching the skin or nail... etc., has not washed the entire hand and has not complied with the command.
The hadith of Aisha and Abdullah bin Amr and others that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Woe to the heels from the Fire" (2). Heels is the plural of heel, which is the back of the foot. The Prophet (peace be upon him) threatened it with Woe because it is common that people are negligent about such things and do not pay attention to them. This indicates that the foot must be washed completely, and Wudu must be performed thoroughly as obligated.
We conclude from this that adopting such things that prevent water from reaching the nail at the time of Wudu or Ghusl is forbidden and impermissible, and Wudu and Ghusl are not valid with it. Even if a woman forgot and bathed, we say her Ghusl is invalid and she must remove such things and then repeat the Ghusl again. Unless she remembered immediately after the Ghusl such that the interval was not long and she was able to remove these things, then it suffices to wash the spot that water did not reach, because order (Tartib) is not obligatory in Ghusl, but continuity (Muwalat) is obligatory according to the correct view, and continuity here has been rectified.

**The Sixth Issue: Artificial Nail Fixtures.**

It is a type of plastic nails resembling natural nails. A woman takes them, paints them with various dyes, then places them on her nail or glues them to her nail with an adhesive substance.
These nails have the same ruling as the aforementioned chemical dyes (nail polish). We say adopting them at the time of Wudu and Ghusl is forbidden and impermissible because, as we mentioned, they prevent water from reaching the nail. It was mentioned earlier that all Imams agree that one of the conditions for the validity of Wudu is removing what prevents water from reaching the skin, such as mud or dough... etc.
Moreover, adopting such nails appears, and Allah knows best, to be forbidden and impermissible because the Lawgiver commanded trimming the nails, as in the hadith of Abu Huraira in the two Sahihs that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: (Five are from the Fitra: Circumcision, shaving pubic hair, plucking armpit hair, trimming nails, and trimming the moustache) (1).
Scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, stated that taking these Sunan has three timings:
First Time: Time of recommendation, which is when these things grow long. If they grow long, it is recommended for a person to take them.
Second Time: Time of dislike (Karahah), which is if they exceed forty days. If they exceed forty days, it is disliked for a person to leave them. That is why in the hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him), he said: "A time limit was set for us in trimming the moustache, trimming nails, plucking armpit hair, and shaving pubic hair, that they should not be left for more than forty nights" (2).
Third Time: If they grow long and become grotesque, then this is forbidden and impermissible. Meaning if he leaves his moustache until it becomes long and grotesque, or leaves his nails until they become long and grotesque, or leaves armpit hair or pubic hair... etc., then this is forbidden and impermissible for two reasons:
1- Because of the resemblance to predatory animals and beasts.
2- Because of the resemblance to the people of disbelief and polytheism.

**The Seventh Issue: Hair Dyes.**
From inductive reasoning, it is noted that the type of dyes women use falls into three categories:

2. Narrated by Muslim and Ibn Majah, and narrated by Ahmad, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and Abu Dawood

First Category: Plant dyes, like henna.
Second Category: Mineral dyes. These mineral dyes consist of metallic compounds containing sulfur, lead, or copper.
Third Category: Hair bleaches or lighteners. These are done using peroxide or hydrogen peroxide. This leads to breaking down the melanin pigment found in the outer cortex of the hair, turning the hair white or yellow, then it is dyed again according to what the woman wants.
This is the first classification regarding the type of dyes.
The second classification regarding the Sharia ruling: We say in terms of Sharia ruling, these dyes are divided into two categories:
First Category: Dyes that are merely color. This is the case for most of these dyes, meaning plant dyes like henna and the like, and also many of the dyes existing today. These are merely color that does not form a mass on the hair nor an insulating layer. We say using these regarding Wudu and Ghusl is permissible and there is no harm in it because such things do not prevent water from reaching; they are merely color coating the hair with another color.
Second Category: That this dye has a mass and layer preventing water from reaching the hair such that the hair becomes thick, which is rare. Using this is not permissible because its period lasts long and a woman needs Ghusl for major impurity like Janabah and menstruation and the like.

**The Eighth Issue: Artificial Eyelashes.**
Artificial eyelashes: Consist of thin hairs made from plastic materials glued to the eyelid by an adhesive placed on the edge of the upper eyelash.
These artificial eyelashes, upon examination and placing in water... etc., are found to decompose. Also, they have openings from the bottom side that do not prevent water from reaching inside the hairs (cilia). If so, meaning these eyelashes if water is put on them and the woman performs Wudu or Ghusl, it is observed that they decompose. Also, they have openings from inside that do not prevent water from reaching the eyelash of the eye.

If this is the case, we say these things do not prevent water from reaching any of the organs that must be washed. So regarding Wudu and Ghusl, we say the woman's Wudu is valid and also her Ghusl is valid.
But the question remains: Is using such eyelashes permissible or not permissible? We say what appears to be the case, and Allah knows best, is that using such eyelashes is not permissible because these artificial eyelashes are placed on natural eyelashes. It is noted that such things are a type of hair extension (Wasl), and the Prophet (peace be upon him) "cursed the woman who joins hair and the one who asks for it to be joined" (1).
The Wasilah (hair joiner): Is the one who joins hair with other hair or what resembles it.
Joining hair is divided into three categories:
First Category: Joining hair with other hair. This is forbidden.
Second Category: Joining hair with something other than hair, like hair made of plastic but it is like hair or close to it in form and shape... etc. This is a subject of disagreement, and what appears, and Allah knows best, is that it is not permissible.
Third Category: Joining hair with something else that is not like hair, far from it, does not resemble or look like it, such as joining it with rags and the like, such that if you see it you don't say it is hair. We say this is permissible and there is no harm in it.
It appears, and Allah knows best, that using these artificial eyelashes is not permissible, not because of Wudu and Ghusl, but because it falls under hair extension (Wasl) since the cause (Illah), which is deception (Zur), for which the Prophet (peace be upon him) gave the ruling, exists here.

Similar to that also is what is found now in some hair clips for women where hair is present in them. The fact that this woman puts this clip which has hair in it, we say regarding Wudu and Ghusl, it appears this does not affect it. Also, some women stuff their hair with other hair; we also say regarding Wudu and Ghusl it does not affect, because water is a thin liquid that permeates such things. But the issue of Wasl (hair extension) remains, and this is what affects the use of such things.

**The Ninth Issue: Use of Greases, Creams, and Powders.**
We say that this issue is divided into two categories:
First Category: That these greases, creams, and powders form merely a color, moisture, or greasiness, like the dyes a woman puts on her face or the creams or greases a woman anoints her body with. We say that these things which are merely greasiness, moisture, or mere color do not prevent water from reaching the skin. Using them does not affect Wudu and does not affect Ghusl. Evidence for this is that water permeates these things. Also, using kohl is commanded in Sharia, using henna is also commanded, dyeing for women... etc.
Second Category: That such things form a dense greasy layer or a waxy layer, such that you find this grease accumulated on the body not just painted. We say this prevents water from reaching the skin.
Similar to that also is what is called today 'Liquid Eyeliner' which a woman applies. This liquid eyeliner is divided into two types:
1: Eyeliner that forms a plastic substance preventing water from reaching the skin; this is not permissible.
2: Eyeliner that dissolves with water and falls off; this does not affect Wudu or Ghusl.

**The Tenth Issue: Catheterization and similarly what is called Artificial Anus (Colostomy) and their effect on purification.**

Catheterization: Is placing a catheter (plastic tube) in the patient's urethra to cause urine discharge without the patient's will. This urine collects in a bag hung in the place where the patient sleeps. The doctor resorts to placing this catheter for the patient: either because the patient cannot urinate naturally or because it is difficult for the patient to go to the toilet. The urine is in a bag next to the patient.
As for Artificial Anus (Colostomy): It is when a patient is afflicted with colon cancer such that he cannot defecate naturally, or the patient has congenital deformities preventing natural defecation. So the doctor resorts to opening a hole in the abdominal wall to facilitate the exit of stool without the patient's will through a tube. There is a container where this stool collects, removed periodically.
What is the effect of this urine on the patient's purity and also on his prayer? And also the exit of this stool on the patient's purity and on his prayer?
This issue builds upon a matter discussed by scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, which is the person with permanent Hadath (incontinence) (whose Hadath is permanent for his obligation). Is Wudu obligatory on him or not? And if we say Wudu is obligatory, must he perform Wudu for the time of every prayer or must he perform Wudu for every prayer?
This issue is a subject of disagreement among scholars, may Allah have mercy on them. Scholars have three opinions on this:
First Opinion: The strictest of schools, which is the Shafi'i school. They say that the one whose Hadath is permanent must perform Wudu for every obligatory prayer. If he performs Wudu for this obligatory prayer, he can pray with this Wudu whatever he wishes of obligatory and voluntary prayers. If he wants to pray another obligatory prayer, he performs Wudu again.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Second Opinion: The Hanafi and Hanbali schools said he does not have to perform Wudu for every prayer, but rather he must perform Wudu for the time of every prayer. They said he must perform Wudu when the time enters and pray whatever he wishes of obligatory and voluntary prayers. When the time for the second prayer comes, he must perform Wudu and pray whatever he wishes of obligatory and voluntary prayers.
Third Opinion: The Maliki school, which is the choice of Sheikh al-Islam (Ibn Taymiyyah), may Allah have mercy on him. It is the broadest of schools in this issue. They said that the one from whom permanent Hadath exits does not have to perform Wudu for every prayer, and Wudu is not invalidated unless another Hadath other than this permanent Hadath exits from him, then he must perform Wudu. For example, this patient from whom urine exits permanently does not have to perform Wudu, but if wind exits from him, he must perform Wudu for this wind, or if stool exits from him, he performs Wudu for this stool.
They excluded from this a case: If the occurrence of the Hadath during the time is a minor matter, meaning most of the time nothing exits from him and it exits from him in a short time, here they said Wudu is obligatory.
The closest of schools is the Maliki school, may Allah have mercy on them. The evidence for that is: The hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: Fatima bint Abi Hubaysh came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, I am a woman who experiences Istihadah (irregular bleeding) and I do not become pure; should I leave prayer? The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "No, that is a vein and not menstruation. When your menstruation comes, leave prayer, and when it goes, wash the blood from yourself then pray" (1).
The Prophet (peace be upon him) did not order the woman with Istihadah to perform Wudu for every prayer. He only guided her to observe menstruation rules during the time of her menstruation only. When the time of menstruation ends, she bathes and prays. Apart from that, it is not obligatory on her.
As for what is narrated of his saying (peace be upon him): "Perform Wudu for every prayer", this phrase is interpolated and not established from the Prophet (peace be upon him).
If we know that, we say this person from whom urine exits permanently does not have to perform Wudu until another Hadath other than this urine occurs.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Similarly, this person who has a natural opening [colostomy], if the exit of stool is continuous, he does not have to perform Wudu for it until another Hadath other than this accidental Hadath occurs. If the exit of this stool is not continuous but is a habitual matter, like people's habit exiting once or twice a day, then he must perform Wudu for the exit of this stool.

**The Eleventh Issue: Kidney Dialysis and its Effect on Purification.**
Kidney failure diseases are considered among the prevalent diseases in our present time. The kidneys perform a major function in the human body; they purify the blood from toxins, liquid wastes, and excess salts. If a person falls ill with this disease and his kidneys fail, this is a dangerous disease threatening his life, and failure to remedy the kidney function leads to the patient's death.
With the development of medicine and its advancement, what is called kidney dialysis appeared in our present time. Kidney dialysis is divided into two types:
First Type: Hemodialysis or blood purification. This is the most common in our present time.
Hemodialysis method: The doctor withdraws the patient's blood through a needle placed in one of the veins. Then this blood passes through a machine that cleans it of toxins, liquid wastes, and excess salts, acting as a natural kidney. During its operation, some medicines, treatments, and nutrients needed by the patient are added to this machine.
This procedure takes place three or four times a week, and each session is estimated at approximately three or four hours depending on the patient's need.
Now, does the exit of this blood and then its reentry into the body after purification invalidate Wudu or does it not invalidate Wudu?
This is a disputed issue among scholars, may Allah have mercy on them. Does bleeding invalidate Wudu or not?
First Opinion: The view of the Malikis and Shafi'is, and the choice of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah. They said that bleeding does not invalidate Wudu, whether the amount is small or large.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship

Second Opinion: The Hanbali school differentiates in this issue. They said if the blood exiting is much, it invalidates Wudu, and if it is little, it does not invalidate Wudu.
Third Opinion: The Hanafi school said if it exits and flows, it invalidates. If it exits and pools without flowing, they said this does not invalidate.
The correct view in this issue: It is what the Malikis and Shafi'is went to, which is that blood exiting from the human body is not invalidating. The evidence for that: The hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him) in the story of the Ansari whom the Prophet (peace be upon him) sent with one of the Muhajireen to be a guard at the mouth of the valley. One of the polytheists hit him with an arrow three times, and blood came out of him, yet he did not cut his prayer but continued his prayer while blood was gushing from him. This hadith was narrated by Ahmad and Abu Dawood, and authenticated by Ibn Hibban, Ibn Khuzaimah, and others. Blood came out of him, yet he continued his prayer. If bleeding invalidated Wudu, he would not have continued his prayer.
Also, Umar (may Allah be pleased with him), as in Sahih Al-Bukhari, prayed while his wound was gushing blood (1).
Also, it was reported from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said regarding Cupping (Hijama), meaning if a person gets cupped: "Wash your cupping places and that suffices you." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and its chain has weakness.
Also, it was reported from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) suspended in Sahih Al-Bukhari that he squeezed a pimple on his face and some blood came out, yet he did not perform Wudu.
Also, this is supported by the principle (Asl) which is that the original state is the continuation of purity, so we do not move from this principle except with evidence indicating that.

Based on this, we say that whoever undergoes this kidney dialysis, which is called Hemodialysis or Blood Purification, the exit of this blood from him then its purification then its return to the body again does not affect Wudu, and he does not have to perform Wudu.
Second Type: Peritoneal Dialysis: It is a tube placed in the patient's abdominal cavity. This tube is placed between the navel and the pubis. The patient is given some fluids and special medicines that help the body get rid of toxins, liquid wastes, and excess salts. Then these toxins, liquid wastes, and excess salts remain collecting in this tube for nearly eight hours while the patient goes about his normal life activities. Then after collection, the patient empties this tube into an external bag, then this bag is sent and another bag is brought... etc. The patient uses this method approximately three times a day according to his need.
Some researchers mentioned that whoever uses Peritoneal Dialysis usually dispenses with natural urination, and this process replaces natural urination.
Jurists discussed this issue under the case: If the original outlet is blocked and another unusual accidental outlet opens, does it take the ruling of the original outlet or not?
This issue is a subject of disagreement among scholars, may Allah have mercy on them:
First Opinion: The famous view of the Hanbali school, may Allah have mercy on them, is differentiation regarding what exits. They said: If what exits is much blood, it invalidates Wudu. If it is little, it does not invalidate Wudu. If what exits is urine or stool, it invalidates whether little or much. As we mentioned in Hemodialysis, the correct view is that bleeding does not invalidate Wudu.
Second Opinion: The Shafi'is said that the exit of these things does not invalidate unless their exit is from below the navel.
Third Opinion: The Hanafis said that the exit of these things invalidates, and they did not differentiate.
Essentially, what exits is divided into two categories:

1 - If it is blood, this does not invalidate.
2 - Or it is other than blood, like urine or stool or what has the characteristics of urine or stool, as in Peritoneal Dialysis. Because Peritoneal Dialysis has the characteristic of urine as it contains toxins, wastes... etc. that are in urine.
So regarding Peritoneal Dialysis: The Hanbali and Hanafi schools hold that it invalidates. The Shafi'i school differentiates: If it is below the navel, it invalidates; if it is above the navel, it does not invalidate.
The closest view in this issue: Peritoneal Dialysis invalidates Wudu because this discharge does not take the ruling of blood, but takes the ruling of urine because it has the characteristics of urine such as wastes, salts, toxins... etc. So we say such a thing invalidates Wudu, unless it is something continuous, but it is not continuous, so it takes the ruling of incontinence (Salas).
The conclusion on that: Peritoneal Dialysis invalidates [Wudu], while Hemodialysis, which is taking out blood, purifying it, then returning it, does not invalidate.

**The Twelfth Issue: Purification of Sewage Water.**
And the ruling on using this purified sewage water for drinking or irrigating farms and green areas or recharging groundwater with such purified water.
Definition of Sewage: It consists of water resulting from human use of water in normal life activities such as washing, cleaning, Istinja (cleaning private parts), and the like.
This sewage water is forbidden to use for three reasons:
First: (Impurity - Najasah) as this sewage contains much human waste.
Second: (Harm) as this sewage contains many toxins and many microbes.
Third: (Filthiness - Istiqdhar) as this sewage is filthy in people's custom and habits.
For sewage to become pure and return to its original state, it passes through stages:
First Stage: Called Pre-treatment Stage. This includes three things:
1 – Removing floating materials and large objects like wood, iron, and plastic materials.
2 – Removing fine sand via sedimentation.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
3 – Removing fats by floating them in special tanks.
Second Stage: Primary Treatment. It precipitates organic materials (human waste) and inorganic materials using a special sedimentation method. This is the first sedimentation stage.
Third Stage: Biological Treatment. After this sedimentation of organic and inorganic materials, a type of aerobic bacteria is grown to feed on these sedimented materials.
Fourth Stage: Secondary Sedimentation Stage. Water retains some suspended materials after the biological stage, so another special sedimentation stage is carried out.
Fifth Stage: Tertiary Treatment Stage, called Sand Filters. This stage consists of removing the remaining suspended materials through sand filters.
Sixth Stage: Sterilization Stage. It is the final stage where this water is sterilized by injecting chlorine gas into the tanks.
These six stages, in terms of Sharia ruling, are divided into two parts:
1 – Secondary Purification.
2 – Final Purification.
Secondary Purification: This is before the Tertiary Treatment Stage (Sand Filters), meaning after the first four stages. If applied completely according to its instructional systems, the water returns to its natural state by 95%. After the Tertiary Treatment Stage and Sand Filters, they say the water mostly returns to its original state and original creation.
Sharia Ruling regarding Secondary Purification differs according to its uses:
First: Using it for drinking and purification: This is not permissible and forbidden because it has not yet become pure as long as 5% remains, and the characteristic of impurity still remains in it.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship

Second: Using it to irrigate crops and trees: This issue is based on a matter discussed by scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, which is the ruling on fertilizing plants and trees with impure things, for example with human waste or waste of animals whose meat is not eaten like donkeys...etc. What is the ruling on fertilizing plants and trees with these impure things?
Scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, differed on this issue into two opinions:
First Opinion: That this is permissible and there is no harm in it. This is the saying of the majority of scholars.
Their evidences:
Among them: What is narrated from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas (may Allah be pleased with him) "that he used to manure his land with human excrement" and say: "A basket of this for two baskets" meaning we put a basket of excrement and get two baskets of wheat or barley and the like. This narration was reported by Al-Bayhaqi and its chain is weak and not established.
Among them: That the original rule is permissibility, and this is what people's customs have run on, and no prohibition came in Sharia regarding it.
Supporting their view is that impurity is purified by transformation (Istihala). Such impurities like excrement and the like transform into grains and fruits. Impurity is purified by transformation as will come to us, God willing. The saying that impurity is purified by transformation is the school of the Zahiris and the choice of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, because this impure substance transformed from one substance to another. For example, if we had a dead animal and this carcass burned and became ash, losing the vile characteristic, we say this ash is pure and there is nothing wrong with it. So if these things become pure by transformation and no harm results from them, we say this is permissible and there is no harm in it.
Also, there is consensus that wine - according to the view of its impurity - becomes pure by transformation (into vinegar). Similarly, they said these things become pure by transformation.
Second Opinion: It is not permissible to manure crops and trees with excrement or impurities. This is the famous view of the Hanbali school.
Their evidence:

What is narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) that he said: "We used to lease land and stipulate on them not to manure it with human excrement." This narration is also weak.
The correct view on this is that fertilizing crops and trees with excrement or impure waste is permissible and there is no harm in it due to the evidence we mentioned.
Thus it becomes clear that this sewage water in its secondary stage is okay to irrigate crops and trees with.
Third: Using it to irrigate parks and gardens with sewage water in its secondary stage, while it has not returned to its original creation and the characteristic of impurity is still in it. This happens often. That is why you find some parks have signs stating they are irrigated with sewage water to warn people against sitting... etc.
Scholars divided this into two types:
1- Green areas where people do not need to sit, but are for beautification. Such action is permissible and there is no harm in it because this harm does not extend to people.
2- Gardens and parks people need to sit in. This builds on a matter scholars discussed, which is the ruling on relieving oneself in places where people sit, or in their paths, or water sources. Scholars have two opinions on this:
First Opinion: Prohibition (Tahrim).
Second Opinion: Dislike (Karahah).
The correct view is that it is forbidden and not permissible. Accordingly, we say irrigating these gardens where people sit with sewage water after the secondary stage is forbidden and not permissible.
The evidence for that: The saying of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in the hadith of Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him): "Beware of the two cursers." They said: What are the two cursers, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "The one who relieves himself in the people's path or in their shade" (1). And Allah Almighty says: {And those who harm believing men and believing women for [something] other than what they have earned have certainly born upon themselves a slander and manifest sin} (2).

text:
Fourth: Using it to recharge groundwater with such water. Meaning if this water is injected into the ground and groundwater is fed with it, is this permissible or not?
This is a point of disagreement among contemporary scholars. The correct view is that it is permissible and there is no harm in it, because the earth and soil are purifying (Tahur) and a purifier. The evidence for that: Allah Almighty said {Allah does not intend to make difficulty for you, but He intends to purify you} (1). And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Clean earth is the Wudu of a Muslim even if he does not find water for ten years" (2).
Also, a number of researchers mentioned that if this water permeates the earth, soil, and sand, it becomes purified by the permission of Allah Almighty, and this stands in place of the third stage, which is the Tertiary Treatment Stage, called Sand Filters.
So it is summarized for us in the Secondary Stage that using this water regarding the Sharia ruling:
First: Using it for eating, drinking, and purification is forbidden and not permissible.
Second: Using it for irrigating trees and crops... etc. is permissible and there is no harm in it.
Third: Using it for irrigating gardens and parks has detail: If people frequent these gardens and parks, it is forbidden and not permissible. If people do not frequent them, it is permissible and there is no harm in it.
Fourth: Recharging groundwater is permissible and there is no harm in it.

The Second Sharia Ruling regarding sewage water after the Tertiary Treatment Stage. They say water returns to its first natural state. Decisions have been issued regarding this, including decisions of the Council of Senior Scholars in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, that water after the Tertiary Treatment Stage, if it returns to its original creation, it is okay to use for purification, drinking, irrigating farms, recharging groundwater... etc.

**The Thirteenth Issue: Organ Transplantation and Transfer and its Effect on Purification.**
In this issue, we will not discuss the ruling of organ transplantation or the ruling of transferring these organs because this is a separate issue. But we will discuss the ruling of this organ if transferred to this body: do we say this organ is pure or impure?
Organ transplantation existed in ancient times but in its primitive stages. It is confirmed that the Prophet (peace be upon him) in the Battle of Badr, when Abu Qatada (may Allah be pleased with him) was struck and his eye bulged out, the Prophet (peace be upon him) took it and returned it, and it became the better of his two eyes even though it had fallen out. This is one of the signs of the Prophet (peace be upon him).
The first to know organ transplantation were the ancient Egyptians through tooth transplantation. Then the Greeks and Romans took this method from them. This was in its primitive stages. Then after that, organ transplantation developed with the development of medicine and advancement of science.
Summary regarding the Sharia ruling for organ transplantation: We say that transplanting organs or transferring them from one body to another or from the patient's body to his own body is divided into categories:
First Category: That the organ is transferred for its owner: for example, transferring bone from one place to another in the body, or skin transferring from one place to another in the same body, or that an organ is severed and falls off like a finger getting cut off or a hand then returned and implanted in the body.
We say that this organ transferred from one place to another in the same body, the four Imams all agree that it is pure.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Second Category: That this skin or bone is transferred from another human, not from the patient himself. For example, we took from the skin of this person and put it in this person, or from his bone... etc. This is also, according to the majority of scholars, a pure organ. This issue builds upon a question: Is the human being pure or not pure? Also his organs and what separated from him, because what is severed from the living is like its dead (carrion). So is the dead human pure? Is there a difference between Muslim and disbeliever?
We say:
First: The living Muslim is pure by agreement. Evidence for that: The saying of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in the hadith of Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him): "Indeed, the believer does not become impure" (Agreed upon).
Second: As for the living disbeliever, is he pure or impure? There are two opinions for scholars:
First Opinion: He is pure. This is the opinion of the majority of scholars.
Their evidence: Allah Almighty permitted Muslims to marry women of the People of the Book and permitted their slaughtered animals. Allah Almighty said: {This day [all] good foods have been made lawful, and the food of those who were given the Scripture is lawful for you and your food is lawful for them. And [lawful in marriage are] chaste women from among the believers and chaste women from among those who were given the Scripture} (1). Undoubtedly, a Muslim man will mix with his wife.
Second Opinion: He is impure. This is the opinion of the Zahiris. They used as evidence the saying of Allah Almighty: {O you who have believed, indeed the polytheists are unclean} (2).
It is answered that the intended meaning is moral impurity, not physical impurity.
The correct view: Is what the majority of scholars went to.
Third: Dead human: The majority view is that it is pure. Hanafis say the dead human is impure, unless he was a Muslim then he becomes pure by washing, but the disbeliever does not become pure even if washed.
The correct view: The dead human, whether disbeliever or Muslim, is pure.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
The evidence for that is what we previously mentioned of evidences for the purity of disbelievers and evidences for Muslims. Also indicating this is that the Prophet (peace be upon him) kissed Uthman bin Maz'un after his death, which indicates he is pure; otherwise, if he became impure by death, the Prophet (peace be upon him) would not have placed his mouth on him.
Conclusion on that: The human is pure whether alive or dead, and whether Muslim or disbeliever. Based on this, we say his organs are pure, and what is severed from him of organs is like his dead body. For example, if skin is cut from him, this skin is like the dead body, and his dead body is pure, so we say it is pure. Whatever bone is cut from him, we say it is like his dead body, and his dead body is pure, so we say it is pure.
So it becomes clear that if some skin, organ, or bone is transferred from a human, whether dead or alive, these things are pure and have no effect on Wudu and prayer, and it is permissible for him to pray with them.
Third Category: Transferring organs from a pure animal to a human. Pure animal: like sea animals and slaughtered animals. For example, if we had a sheep, slaughtered it, took its bone, and took it to a human whose bone was broken. Jurists have stated the transfer of bones. Or we took some skin and implanted it in human skin... etc. We say these things are pure, have no effect on prayer or Wudu, and this is permissible by agreement of Imams.
Fourth Category: Transferring impure organs to a human, such as the carrion of cattle and pigs... etc. Doctors have mentioned that pig bone is one of the best bones in suitability for human bone, healing quickly and not leading to curvature.
If pig bone is transferred to a human, or a dead sheep whose bone we took without slaughtering and transferred to a human who had a fracture, what is the ruling? We say the principle is that this is forbidden and impermissible because carrion is impure and pig is also forbidden and impermissible.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Although Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, regards bones of carrion as pure, according to the opinion of the majority of scholars who view them as impure, they see it is not permissible to transfer such impure organs, e.g., skin, bones, tooth, pig bone... etc.
However, the issue of necessity (Idtirar) remains. If a person is compelled to such things, we say this is permissible with two conditions:
First Condition: That this is after searching and investigation, meaning he searches for the medicine that suits him. If he exerts his effort in searching and investigating and does not find anything pure, then it is permissible for him to resort to the impure.
Second Condition: That it be a case of necessity, meaning he is in need of it and compelled to it. But if he is not compelled, it is not permissible.
So it is summarized for us regarding organ transfer that it is divided into four categories:
1 - From the human himself to his body: This is permissible by agreement.
2 - From a human: This is permissible according to the majority of scholars, whether that human is Muslim or disbeliever, alive or dead.
3 - From a pure animal like sea animals and slaughtered cattle: This is permissible by agreement.
4 - From an impure animal: This is not permissible, but the issue of necessity applies.

**The Fourteenth Issue: Detergents containing impurities in their composition, such as soap and others containing pig fat or alcohol.**
What is the ruling of these detergents?
First: Regarding soap and other detergents containing impurities in their composition, we say: These impurities are one of two cases:
First Case: If these impure compounds dissolved, melted, and were consumed due to mixing with other materials, using such soap containing small percentages of pig fat etc., which dissolved and were consumed, is permissible and there is no harm in it. Because this fat has no effect left. Ibn Rajab, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned a rule for that: That the substance which is immersed in another and consumed has no ruling.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Second Case: If these impure compounds transformed (Istahalat) and changed into another substance. We also say that transformation (Istihala) changes impure substances into pure substances, transferring them from impure to pure, as is the Zahiri school and choice of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah. For example, if we had a dog, then this dog burned and turned into ash and smoke, this ash is pure, because the impure substance transformed and transferred from one substance to another.
The evidence that impurity becomes pure by transformation: Scholars agreed that wine, if it transforms by itself, turns from an impure substance according to the majority to a pure substance. Similar to that are the worms of latrines; these worms emerge from impurities yet transform into a pure animal.
Third Case: If these compositions still remain, like pig fat or carrion fat still remaining, not transformed or consumed in others. Is it permissible to use such soap or detergent in whose composition this impurity entered and remains?
This is a subject of disagreement among scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, regarding the ruling of using impurity in a way that does not transmit (its impurity). There are two opinions for scholars:
First Opinion: Using such soap is not permissible. This is the opinion of most scholars.
Their evidence: The Lawgiver commanded avoiding impurities, and commanded Istinja and Istijmar.
Second Opinion: Using such soap is permissible for need, if it is in a way that does not transmit, meaning if it is not used in prayer or eating and drinking... etc. This is the choice of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him.
His evidence: The hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saying in the Year of Conquest while he was in Mecca: "Indeed, Allah and His Messenger have forbidden the sale of wine, dead animals, swine, and idols." It was said: O Messenger of Allah, what about the fat of dead animals? For ships are coated with it, skins are oiled with it, and people use it for lamps? He said: "No, it is Haram." (Agreed upon).

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
The Prophet (peace be upon him) approved their saying: skins are oiled with it, people use it for lamps, and ships are coated with it, even though carrion fat is impure. Yet, the Prophet (peace be upon him) approved them utilizing it, and said: "No, it is Haram" regarding the sale.
Second: Some cosmetics which use impurities in their composition like pig fat, for example. We say as preceded: If this impurity was consumed in others or transformed, meaning transferred from one substance to another, then these tools are pure and permissible to use.
If this impurity still remains in such tools, the previous disagreement applies: Using them at prayer time if remaining, we say is not permissible. If using them outside prayer, we said: Most scholars say this is not permissible. According to Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah's view, this is permissible due to the evidence we mentioned.
Third: Using cosmetics containing parts of embryos (fetuses). We say using these tools is forbidden and not permissible, even if these embryos were consumed or transformed from one substance to another and no trace remained. The evidence for that:
The principle regarding the human being is sanctity (Hurmah). Proceeding with such a thing is fundamentally forbidden and not permissible. Allah Almighty says: {And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference} Al-Isra 70.
Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): "Indeed your blood and your wealth are sacred to you like the sanctity of this day of yours, in this month of yours, in this land of yours...".

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Hadith "The blood of a Muslim is not lawful except in one of three cases..." (1).
Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Breaking the bone of the dead is like breaking it while alive" (2). Which indicates that his sanctity remains even after his death.
The Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade sitting on a grave and walking on it (3).
Selling a human is among the major sins, even if he is a disbeliever, because the principle for children of Adam is freedom. Due to the hadith: "Three people Allah will not speak to, nor purify, nor look at on the Day of Resurrection... one who sold a free person and ate his price" (4).
This includes selling embryos and introducing them into industries and cosmetics.

**Contemporary Issues Related to Rulings of Prayer**
**1- Issues Related to Conditions of Prayer**
**First: Regarding Time:**
**The First Issue: Does anything like calculation substitute for cosmic horizontal signs or not?**
foot_note:

2. Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawood, and Ibn Majah. Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Aisha as Marfu' (raised to Prophet). Ibn Al-Qattan classified it Hasan. Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid said it is on the condition of Muslim. Al-Daraqutni narrated it from her and added "in sin". Malik mentioned it in Al-Muwatta as Balagh (report without chain) from Aisha as Mawquf (stopped at companion). Ibn Majah narrated it from Umm Salamah.
3. From Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (That one of you sits on an ember which burns his clothes and reaches his skin is better than for him to sit on a grave). Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah.
4. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Ahmad.

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
Time is a condition for the validity of prayer by agreement of scholars. The evidence for that: The saying of Allah Almighty: {Establish prayer at the decline of the sun [from its meridian] until the darkness of the night and [also] the Qur'an of dawn. Indeed, the recitation of dawn is ever witnessed} (1). Also His saying Almighty: {Indeed, prayer has been decreed upon the believers a decree of specified times} Al-Nisa 103 (2). The hadiths on times are many, and one of the most authentic is the hadith of Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both), which is a verbal hadith and more preponderant than the hadith of Gabriel leading the Prophet (peace be upon him) as in the hadith of Jabir and Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them).
From the ease and facilitation of Sharia is that it linked prayer times to cosmic horizontal signs seen by everyone, not hidden from them, realized by the scholar, the ignorant, the city dweller, and the Bedouin.
We find that (Fajr Prayer): Its time enters with the rise of the second dawn and lasts until sunrise.
(Zuhr Prayer): Its time enters with the sun's decline (Zawal) and lasts until the shadow of everything becomes equal to it, excluding the shadow of Zawal.
(Asr Prayer): Lasts until the sun turns yellow, then a time of necessity until sunset.
(Maghrib Prayer): From sunset until the disappearance of the twilight.
(Isha Prayer): From the disappearance of twilight until midnight.
Does anything like calculation substitute for these cosmic horizontal signs or not? We find people today, due to abundant lights, expansion of buildings, and high-rise buildings in big cities and even small towns... etc., have turned away from these cosmic horizontal signs and relied on what is called calculation, calendars, watches, and also computer devices existing now which determine prayer time in any city in the world not just for a day or two or a month or two, but for years.
What is the validity of a Muslim relying on such calendars, watches, and devices like computers for his prayer?

text:
Al-Qarafi (may Allah have mercy on him) mentioned a difference between Ramadan and Prayer (1). He said that regarding Ramadan, the Lawgiver commanded us with only one of two things and did not look at calculation:
First Matter: Sighting the crescent moon, which is a cosmic horizontal sign perceivable by all.
Second Matter: Completing the count. If we are unable to see the crescent, we complete the count of thirty days.
That is why the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Fast upon sighting it and break fast upon sighting it, and if it is obscured from you, complete the count" (2). In Sahih Al-Bukhari: "Then count Sha'ban as thirty" (3).
As for calculation in Ramadan, the Lawgiver invalidated it and did not consider it, due to the saying of the Prophet (peace be upon him): "We are an unlettered nation, we do not write or calculate. The month is like this and like this and like this, or like this and like this and like this" (4), meaning he folded his thumb in the third instance, meaning the month is either thirty days or twenty-nine days.
As for calculation in prayer times, the Lawgiver considered it. The evidence for that:

3. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in the chapter of the Prophet's saying: If you see the crescent, fast, and if you see it, break fast (1810). He said: Adam told us, Shu'ba told us, Muhammad bin Ziyad told us, he said I heard Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) saying: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said - or Abu Al-Qasim (peace be upon him) said - (Fast upon sighting it and break fast upon sighting it, and if it is hidden from you, complete the count of Sha'ban as thirty). 
4. From the hadith of Abdullah bin Umar: Narrated by Al-Bukhari no: 1913, Muslim no: 1080, Abu Dawood no: 2319, Al-Nasa'i: 4 / 139

The hadith of the Dajjal (Antichrist). The Prophet (peace be upon him) informed the Companions about the Dajjal's stay, saying: "He will stay forty days: a day like a year, a day like a month, and a day like a week." They said: O Messenger of Allah, this day which is like a year, will the prayer of one day suffice us in it? He said: "No, estimate for it its measure." How do we estimate for it? Al-Nawawi and other scholars mentioned how to estimate for this day which is the length of a year. Similarly in such days where people need calculation due to the expansion of cities and spread of lights. The Imams agreed that calculation is considered in prayer, although they do not consider it in Ramadan. They say that if the time of prayer is known either through industry or tested mechanism, a person may pray.
So it became clear to us that relying on such instruments yields probability (Zann) of the time entering. Probability of time entry is permissible to act upon in Sharia. Evidence for that is the hadith of Asma' in Sahih Al-Bukhari (1). Asma' mentioned that they broke their fast during the time of the Prophet (peace be upon him) on a cloudy day, then the sun appeared. This indicates they built upon probability. If they built upon certainty, the sun would not have appeared. But the sun appearing indicates they thought the sun had set, yet they broke fast. This indicates relying on probability regarding entry of time as well as its exit.
Second: Regarding covering the 'Awrah (nakedness).

**The Second Issue: Praying in Trousers (Pants).**
Praying in trousers was not present in previous times, so contemporary scholars differed on it. Trousers are a type of Sirwal (drawers) but characterized by being tight and thick, covering from navel to ankle, and maybe lower than the ankle. Praying in trousers is a new matter not present among Muslims in past times; it transferred to Muslims from the West. Al-Albani (may Allah have mercy on him) said: These trousers have two calamities: First calamity is resemblance to disbelievers, Second calamity is defining the 'Awrah (showing shape).

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship

Regarding resemblance to disbelievers, it has now become in some Islamic countries a clothing of Muslims and has become widespread, so it is no longer specific to disbelievers. The Salaf disliked the Burnus (hooded cloak), yet Imam Malik (may Allah have mercy on him) was asked about the Burnus and said there is no harm in it. They said Christians wear it. He said: It is worn here. This indicates that if something spreads among Muslims and is not specific to disbelievers, there is no harm in it unless it implies a Sharia prohibition, like being of religious symbols.
Regarding the second calamity mentioned by Sheikh Al-Albani (may Allah have mercy on him), which is defining the 'Awrah by shape: regarding defining the 'Awrah, jurists (may Allah have mercy on them) agree that praying in tight clothes is permissible and okay regarding the prayer itself, unlike wearing it which many scholars dislike. If it leads to Fitnah (temptation), it is forbidden.
The evidence that wearing tight clothes is permissible is the hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said regarding the garment: "If it is wide, wrap yourself in it, and if it is tight, tie it around your waist" (1). Al-Bukhari titled a chapter: Chapter of Praying in Tight Garments.
Based on this, we say whoever prays in these trousers, his prayer is valid and permissible. But wearing these tight trousers is at least Makruh (disliked) because scholars disliked that. But whoever is afflicted with these trousers, like one accustomed to wearing them or vocational workers, we say he should strive to widen these trousers and not make them describe and define the 'Awrah.

**The Third Issue: The Praying Person Carrying Pictures.**
Most people are afflicted with carrying pictures. It could be pictures in ID cards, pictures in money, or pictures in job cards, as some employees might put the picture in their pocket or on their front and are required to do so.

Regarding the ruling of carrying these pictures, there are two opinions for scholars:
First Opinion: The famous view of the Hanbali school is that the prayer of one carrying a picture is Makruh (disliked).
Second Opinion: The Hanafis and Shafi'is said: This is permissible and not Makruh.
The basis for this is the hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) in Sahih Al-Bukhari, that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Remove your Qiram (1) from us, for its pictures keep distracting me in my prayer" (2).
Al-Ayni (may Allah have mercy on him) said in Umdat al-Qari Sharh Sahih Al-Bukhari: "If this prohibition is regarding the house in which one prays, then being in the garment in which the person prays containing pictures is more worthy (of prohibition)."
The closer view in this issue: Such pictures are permissible and there is no harm in them, as per the Fatwa of the Permanent Committee for Scholarly Research and Ifta (3). Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Sa'di (may Allah have mercy on him) said: However, necessary things that entered upon people and became a widespread affliction like pictures in money, matchboxes, and passports, what appears is that this is from necessity and widespread affliction (Umum al-Balwa), pardon is hoped from Allah regarding it, and the matter is eased.
Scholars (may Allah have mercy on them) infer that such matters are eased by the fact that the Salaf carried Frankish coins which bore pictures of kings and animals, indicating that such is permissible and no harm. There is also evidence that these objects are humiliated by taking and giving. Also, some scholars said polytheists used to worship large images, whereas such pictures are small, so resemblance is negated, meaning the carrier of this picture is not resembling idol worshippers.

Based on this, we say such things appear to be permissible, no harm in them, and not Makruh. But some employees are afflicted with hanging the picture (ID badge); we say it is better to keep this picture covered in his pocket during prayer, because many scholars justified the permissibility of such pictures in money and cards by the fact that they are mostly covered and not visible.

**Third: Issues Related to Adhan:**
**The Fourth Issue: Adhan via Recorder.**
Is this considered worship sufficient for the communal obligation? And also, do we say we should answer it if we hear it? Or do we say it is not worship and not prescribed?
We say this Adhan via recorder is not prescribed, and it is feared to be an innovation (Bid'ah).
The evidence for that:
1.  Worship is Tawqifi (dependent on text). Allah Almighty says: {Or have they partners who have legislated for them a religion to which Allah has not consented?} (1). And He Almighty says: {And the Day He will call them and say, "What did you answer the messengers?"} (2).
2.  Adhan is worship requiring intention (Niyyah), due to the hadith "Actions are but by intentions" (3), and such is not achieved by this recorder.
3.  Also, what some late scholars mentioned that relying on such a recorder misses many Sunan, etiquettes, and rulings of the Mu'adhin. The Mu'adhin has Sunan, etiquettes, and conditions. Among Sunan: turning right and left, purity, facing Qibla... etc. These things do not exist in this recorder. Among conditions of Adhan is that the Mu'adhin be a sane male Muslim, and this does not apply to the recorder.
For these reasons mentioned, Adhan from this recorder is incorrect, does not suffice for the communal obligation, is not sufficient for legitimacy if there is someone to call Adhan and drop the communal obligation, and rulings of Adhan like answering the Mu'adhin etc. do not apply to it.

**The Fifth Issue: Is it prescribed to answer the Mu'adhin who calls Adhan via machines like the Radio...**

book_title: Fiqh of Contemporary Issues in Worship
text:
If Adhan is transmitted via radio, does it have the ruling of Adhan in terms of answering it if we hear it, or does it not take the ruling of Adhan so we don't answer it? For example, a person turned on the radio and heard Adhan being called in such-and-such country, does he answer this Mu'adhin and say the Adhan remembrances and supplication? Or do we say this Adhan is not answered?
We say this transmitted Adhan is divided into two categories (1):
First Category: That it be transmitted live directly. This is answered. If you hear the Mu'adhin, you follow him and answer him. Evidence is the general statement of the Prophet: "If you hear the call, say like what the Mu'adhin says" (2). This includes whether Adhan is in the person's country or another country. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) mentioned that it is recommended to answer a second, third, and fourth Mu'adhin, because Adhan is Dhikr (remembrance) and Dhikr is commanded, and that falls under the Prophet's (peace be upon him) saying: "If you hear the call, say like what the Mu'adhin says" (3).
Second Category: That this Adhan be a recording as mentioned, as some radio stations do. We say this is not prescribed to be answered. We mentioned previously that the origin of this Adhan is not prescribed and it is feared to be an innovation because worship acts are Tawqifi as we mentioned.

**The Sixth Issue: Turning (right and left) during Adhan in Loudspeakers, is it prescribed or not?**
In previous times, the Mu'adhin used to climb the minaret or tower and call Adhan. Evidence for this is that Bilal (may Allah be pleased with him) used to call Adhan on the house of a woman from Banu Najjar, and her house was the highest house near the mosque" (4).

From this, scholars (may Allah have mercy on them) derived that it is recommended to call Adhan on a high place. This is supported by being more effective in calling, announcing, and alerting people to prayer, because the purpose of Adhan is informing people of prayer so they attend it.
Now in many countries, they do not rely on this, and you don't find the Mu'adhin climbing the tower or a high place to call Adhan. Rather, he suffices with calling Adhan at the bottom, and Adhan is broadcast via loudspeakers found on the tower where sound amplification happens.
If he was calling Adhan on the minaret or a high place, the Sunnah is to turn. This Sunnah is supported by the hadith of Abu Juhayfah "that he saw Bilal calling Adhan, and I began following his mouth here and there, right and left, saying Hayya 'ala al-Salah, Hayya 'ala al-Falah" (1).
But regarding now, the one calling Adhan into loudspeakers, do we say the Sunnah is for him to turn, or do we say the Sunnah is to leave turning?
This is a point of disagreement among late scholars (may Allah have mercy on them):
First Opinion: He leaves turning.
Their evidences:
- Among them: The wisdom of the Mu'adhin turning right and left is to convey to all directions: right, left, front, and back. Now the wisdom is negated, so it is not prescribed to turn.
- Among them: They also said that turning right or left weakens the voice because he will turn away [from the microphone], so it is not prescribed to turn.
Second Opinion: Remaining on the original Sunnah, because this is an established Sunnah in the two Sahihs, so it is prescribed for the Mu'adhin to turn.
